name: Kobuk Valley National Park
description: Caribou, sand dunes, the Kobuk River, Onion Portage - just some of the facets of Kobuk Valley National Park. Thousands of caribou migrate through, their tracks crisscrossing sculpted dunes. The Kobuk River is an ancient and current corridor for people and wildlife. For 9000 years, people came to Onion Portage to harvest caribou as they swam the river. Even today, that rich tradition continues.
shortDescription: Caribou, sand dunes, the Kobuk River, Onion Portage - just some of the facets of Kobuk Valley National Park. Thousands of caribou migrate through, their tracks crisscrossing sculpted dunes. The Kobuk ...

operatingHours.description: The Northwest Arctic Heritage Center is the visitor center for Kobuk Valley National Park.  Since there are no roads in to Kobuk Valley, the visitor center is located in Kotzebue, AK.  From Kotzebue, visitors will charter an air taxi to transport them into the actual national park which is open 24/7 every day of the year.

climate.weatherDescription: Snow, rain, and freezing temperatures can occur any time of the year. Always travel with good quality rain gear and warm layers. Be especially careful to stay dry. Hypothermia can set in on a windy, wet day, even when it doesn't feel that cold.

images.title: Kobuk Sand Dunes
images.caption: The setting sun casts shadows of black spruce on the dunes and colors the water of Ahnewetut Creek a deep blue.

images.title: Canoe on the Kobuk River
images.altText: A green pack canoe sits on the bank of the Kobuk River. Clouds are mirrored on the water's surface.
images.caption: A quick pause on a canoe trip down the Kobuk River.

images.title: Mountains as Far as the Eye Can See
images.altText: aerial view of snow capped mountains
images.caption: The peaks of the Baird Mountains stretch far into the distance and are so remote that many of them have not been named.

images.title: The Jade Mountains reflected in the Kobuk River
images.altText: The Jade Mountains reflected in the Kobuk River
images.caption: The Jade Mountains reflected in the Kobuk River as seen near Onion Portage.

images.title: Kobuk Locoweed
images.caption: Oxytropis kobukensis (Kobuk Locoweed) is a member of the pea family and adds a splash of pink to the sand dunes. The blossoms have that typical pea/ bean flower shape that many gardeners know.

images.title: Left Behind
images.altText: Caribou bone sitting in the sand
images.caption: Caribou migrate across the Great Kobuk Sand Dunes, heading north in the summer and south in the fall. Some survive and some don't, which is a reality of life

images.title: Lone Rangifer tarandus
images.altText: Single caribou with antlers in velvet
images.caption: A single caribou of the 240,000+ strong Western Arctic herd on its fall migration south across Kobuk Valley National Park.

images.title: A rainbow over Niaktovik Creek
images.altText: Dark skies shadow the horizon. A rainbow is illuminated above Niaktovik Creek
images.caption: Dark skies shadow the horizon. A rainbow is illuminated above Niaktovik Creek.
images.credit: NPS Photo / Amy Martin (2022 Artist in Residence)
